The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to other foundational problems in mathematics. However, the category of linear operators on a Hilbert space is not a category of mathematical objects, because it does not have all the properties that are required of mathematical objects. We provide a set of axioms that guarantee that the category of continuous linear operators on a Hilbert space is equivalent to the category of mathematical objects.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Read more)

The ability of the immune system to recognize and eliminate pathogens is a key component of the host defense mechanism. In the case of viruses, the immune system can recognize them through the production of interferons (IFNs), which are a family of cytokines that are able to induce the expression of a large number of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are responsible for the expression of a large number of ISGs. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by interfering with the nuclear import pathway. Our results provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used as a starting point for the development of new antiviral strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. In this study, we show that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the future, and that this instability will be particularly severe in the world’s major maize-producing countries. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are adapted to a warmer climate.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the mechanisms that maintain biodiversity in natural ecosystems. However, the extent to which different species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa from DNA sequences. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for more comprehensive studies of diet partitioning in large mammal assemblages. This will be critical for understanding the mechanisms that maintain biodiversity in natural ecosystems.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. We also assess the take-up rates and business resilience effects of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris larger than 1 mm by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most fundamental questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the solar system because it is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system in detail. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of life. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. Finally, this study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would have important implications for the treatment of MSA. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and is the target of many drugs. The endothelium is a network of cells that is connected to each other by a network of channels that allow for the exchange of information. The network of channels is surprisingly complex and is not well understood. Here, we use a combination of imaging and mathematical modeling to understand the structure and function of the endothelial network. We find that the network is highly connected and that the information is transmitted rapidly. This allows for the endothelium to rapidly respond to changes in the environment. The findings have implications for the design of the endothelium and for the development of drugs that target the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In response, we have developed the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary indicators that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These indicators are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to researchers, policy makers, and the public.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the natural products that are produced by the microbes that inhabit the gut are poorly characterized. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gut of herbivores. These fungi are important members of the gut microbiome and are currently used as a source of enzymes for industrial applications. Our results suggest that these fungi are also a source of natural products that could be used for therapeutic and industrial applications.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms that determine who becomes dominant in a group remain unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance in rats. We identify an important mediating role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. In particular, we show that high-anxious animals are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this low probability to become dominant is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and fabricate structures that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the principle of least constraint energy. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work can also inspire the design of other complex systems.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a major regulator of the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. The Hb system is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and miRNAs. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the Hb system in humans. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the Hb system in erythroid cells. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the Hb system in humans. Our results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This study may also have implications for the development of hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy, and the survival of many patients is limited by the development of drug resistance. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers cancer cells resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis. Finally, we demonstrated that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is the class of drugs that block voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channels (LCCBs). The three major classes of LCCBs are widely used in clinical practice. However, the mechanisms of action of these drugs are not fully understood. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our data also indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in patients with heart failure, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. These findings may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in clinical practice. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP had the intended effect on biodiversity. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition, but the effects of the NWFP on older-forest–associated birds were not as expected. Instead, declines of older-forest–associated birds accelerated, partly due to the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP has been successful in halting clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. These findings underscore the need for adaptive management and the importance of monitoring to evaluate the effects of policies on biodiversity. (Read more)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. To combat this problem, we developed a rational design strategy to identify new acylide antibiotics. We used a computational approach to predict the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We then synthesized the top-ranked compounds and tested them in vitro for their inhibitory activity. We also tested the compounds in vivo against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compound designed by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, the current best antibiotic for the treatment of infections caused by multidrug-resistant pathogens. The best compound is also more soluble and exhibits higher binding affinity toward the ribosome. The compounds designed by us are promising candidates for the treatment of infections caused by antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed network architecture is a promising alternative to popular existing architectures.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse fish assemblages on Earth. The lake has been described as a living laboratory for studying the evolution of biodiversity. The lake is also a unique archive of climate change, with a continuous 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate from Lake Malawi. The record shows dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The record also shows evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. The shift in hydroclimate is consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, reduces the evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, all of which have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climate event that occurred 11,600 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the Younger Dryas boundary (YDB). We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust (= 1.3), indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult is unknown. Here, we report that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, but not in the fetus. We also show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, but not in the fetus.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of phylogenomic and transcriptomic analyses to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls, and to trace the evolution of beetle lineages. We found that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes. We propose that these novel genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, it was only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. We conclude that larger populations do not enhance artifact performance via CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the role of social learning in the transmission of cultural artifacts. They also have implications for the design of evolutionary experiments.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD risk by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is about 1,700 km in diameter and 1,500 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, and it is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the rest of the Earth. The inner core is a mystery to us. It is not clear how it formed, and it is not clear how it has been evolving since it formed. In this paper, we propose a new mechanism for the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings have implications for the understanding of the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process. Despite this, the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict the majority of the neural responses to language in the human brain. This suggests that the mechanisms for language comprehension in the brain are fundamentally shaped by predictive coding. We also find that the networks’ architecture contributes to their neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism for understanding the brain’s processing of meaning.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear why DL works so well, and why it is so difficult to train a neural network to compute a specific function. We address this paradox by showing that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the limits of science. The pandemic is a product of human behavior, not a scientific phenomenon. The scientific community is now debating the role of misinformation and conspiracy theories in the spread of the virus. This debate is based on a flawed understanding of the psychology of misinformation. This article discusses the psychology of misinformation and the role of the classic 1974 experiment by Petty and Cacioppo in the spread of misinformation.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for millennia, and its causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research for more than a century. Despite this, we still do not know the identity of the pathogen that causes the reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a pathogen that causes the classic form of leprosy, lepromatous disease. Phylogenetic analyses suggest that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of the leprosy pathogens than is M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for the study of ancient leprosy pathogens. (Read more)

The evolution of entanglement is a key question in quantum information science. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We use integrability to describe the quasiparticles in the steady state, and we use the dynamics of these quasiparticles to describe the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we find perfect agreement.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain that was developed by codon-pair deoptimization. The vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, has a furin cleavage site deletion, and generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies. The vaccine candidate is also able to protect hamsters from lethal challenge with wild-type SARS-CoV-2. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Thus, the vaccine candidate described here may be a valuable addition to the arsenal of COVID-19 vaccines. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was better able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model outbreaks, which allows for the inclusion of many data points and the consideration of uncertainty. This is particularly important for outbreaks that are poorly documented, such as the Black Death. Our results also show the potential of using historical mortality data to study the transmission of infectious diseases in the past. This approach could be used to study other diseases, such as cholera.

The evolution of brain size is a key factor in understanding the rise of complex cognition. However, it is not the only factor. The number of neurons is the brain’s basic computational unit. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a rationale for the development of TRAP1-directed therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is thought to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF-induced severing is enhanced by a mechanical torque that is generated by the connection geometry. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanism for how mechanical forces can be used to control the activity of ADF, which is important for understanding its role in cell migration and cancer metastasis. Our findings also have implications for understanding the role of mechanical forces in other biological processes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. In addition, the findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may be a potential target for the development of interventions to reduce the risk of overeating. This study also highlights the importance of controlling for the fasted state in studies of the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. The results suggest that the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain may be more pronounced in a fed state. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The recent demographic growth is supported by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island, which is sex biased and heterogeneous. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world. It also provides a reference for the future studies on the human history of Madagascar. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence our own. We show that this occurs even when the people we are influenced by are not in our immediate social network. This suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. They also suggest that the observation of others’ negative experiences can be a negative experience for people. This work also has implications for the design of social media platforms. We show that the design of social media platforms can influence the emotions of their users. Finally, we suggest that the design of social media platforms should consider the influence of the emotions of others on people’s emotions. This work also suggests that the design of social media platforms can influence the emotions of their users.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of chemical modifications in the sequence of mRNAs can alter their structure and function. In this work, we show that the most common modification of mRNA, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA sequences can have a significant impact on the rate of protein synthesis in cells. This work also highlights the importance of considering the context of mRNA modifications in the ribosome binding site when predicting the effects of modifications on translation. This study provides a foundation for understanding the impact of mRNA modifications on translation and the consequences of changes in translation rate on the physiology of cells. (Read more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and are not explained by factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, or prosperity. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We use a quantitative approach to test the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven to larger body sizes by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment. We find that the evolution of aquatic mammals is consistent with the hypothesis that the energetic demands of the aquatic environment are driving the evolution of larger body sizes. This work provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on body size in mammals and suggests that the evolution of aquatic mammals is not an exception to the laws of evolutionary biology.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Despite the prevalence of rhinovirus, the mechanisms that determine the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication are not well understood. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at nasal cavity temperature than at core body temperature. We also show that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is dependent on the innate immune response of infected cells. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and therapeutics for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment, and the ability to respond to environmental cues is essential for survival. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This mechanosensory mechanism is mediated by the type IV pili, which are used for twitching motility and for sensing surfaces. The pili-mediated surface sensing results in a positive feedback that increases the activity of the pili, thereby promoting long-term surface attachment that can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. This study demonstrates that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing may be a general mechanism used by bacteria to sense their environment. Understanding the mechanisms used by bacteria to sense their environment is important for understanding the evolution of bacterial motility and virulence. This study also provides a model for the evolution of mechanosensitive signaling systems in bacteria.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of pesticide contamination of surface waters. We also show that the use of pesticides is widespread and that the risk of pesticide contamination of surface waters is high. This study provides a basis for further research on the effects of pesticides on aquatic biodiversity and for the development of improved pesticide regulations.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are low. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of wildlife in the COVID-19 pandemic. (Read more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. The paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of much research. However, the role of Aβ in the earliest stages of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are toxic to neurons, and that they are the primary cause of an early inflammatory response. We also show that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of inflammation in the brain, and that this response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD. They also suggest that the Aβ hypothesis may be incomplete, and that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. This may have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD. Finally, our findings may have broader implications for the understanding of the role of inflammation in neurodegenerative diseases.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein in high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied for many years. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is a complex process that involves distinct steps and intermediates. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism used by bacteria to encode the presence of stress-induced transcripts. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing this cap, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, prefers to remove the cap from Np4-capped transcripts over the other phosphorylated forms of the same RNA. This preference is due to the fact that the cap of Np4-capped RNAs is recognized by the enzyme by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. The unique manner in which Np4-capped 5′ ends bind to the active site of the enzyme positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This deprotection step is required to produce the monophosphorylated 5′ terminus needed to stimulate rapid RNA degradation.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to increase arginine availability and restore T cell function and proliferation in a mouse model of sepsis. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a therapeutic strategy in other conditions in which arginine is depleted. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass contains more consumers than producers. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are a step forward in understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change of the system’s energy is approximately constant. SOC systems are often described by a sandpile model, where the energy is the number of unstable sites. In this paper, we describe a continuous model of SOC, which is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy applications. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, and its bandgap can be tuned continuously. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly through strain engineering, and its bandgap can be tuned continuously. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also relevant to other materials with wide bandgaps, such as boron nitride and silicon carbide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The structural and functional characterization of a peptide with a unique structure and antifungal activity against plant fungal pathogens is described here. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this peptide and its potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This study also provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this peptide and its potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the male–female proteome hand-off is extensive, with multiple proteins initially associating with sperm and then being transferred to the female reproductive tract. These female-derived proteins are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and the public interested in the molecular basis of sex differences. (Read more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the force-dependent pathway is a major contributor to the observed effects of VWD mutations. These results provide a mechanism for the effects of VWD mutations on platelet binding and may be relevant to other diseases involving conformational regulation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study addresses this gap by analyzing over 10,000 publicly available metagenomic datasets. The results are used to identify over 2,200 virus–disease associations, and to show that the virome is more important for disease than the bacteriome. This study is a major step forward in understanding the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature history of Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of Earth’s surface is inferred to have decreased over geological time, a finding that is consistent with both geologic and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. However, the geologic record is subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. The thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes provides an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow across the plasma membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are open or closed, and the open probability is regulated by the channel’s internal and external signals. The open probability is also regulated by the channel’s conformational changes, which are controlled by the channel’s pore gates. Ion channels have two types of pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to invade the host cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single binding antigen, EBA175, to alter the physical properties of the erythrocyte, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This finding has implications for the design of antimalarial drugs that target the parasite, as well as for the development of strategies to reduce the energy barrier to invasion. This work also highlights the importance of considering the host cell in the invasion process. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy applications. However, diamond is a brittle material, and its mechanical properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, and we identify the strain pathway to metallization. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly through strain engineering, and we identify the strain pathway to demetallization. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We found that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection in the context of environmental factors. They also provide a rationale for the use of low humidity as a therapeutic strategy to reduce disease severity in influenza virus infection. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how left-hemispheric brain activity varies during the formation of phrase structures. We found that each additional word or multiword phrase contributed a similar amount of additional brain activity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Formal model comparison indicated that the model of multiword phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most sites in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in many developmental processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt pathway. We believe that this is a common feature in vertebrates and that it may be used to distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. The mechanisms that regulate food intake and body weight are not well understood. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the pars reticulata of the substantia nigra. Finally, we show that this circuit is dependent on noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus. These findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms that regulate food intake and body weight. They may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. Nitrogen fixation is a sustainable and efficient way to deliver nitrogen to the plant, but the symbiosis is often lost when the plant is transplanted, and the bacteria are exposed to a different plant species. Here, we demonstrate a system in which the plant can control the nitrogen fixation in the bacteria, so that the bacteria only fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen to the plant in a sustainable way, without the need for chemical fertilizers.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results also suggest that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Our results have implications for the design of forest monitoring and governance systems in the Amazon and elsewhere.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine or treatment. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-known to mediate viral entry to cells. This variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, a high-yield manufacturability profile, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. Antibodies raised against the engineered protein exhibited heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern (VOCs). Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a useful tool for vaccine development and for the treatment of COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALKAL family of proteins is implicated in the development of several cancer types. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate the ALK/LTK family of receptors in vivo. We further show that ALKALs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in zebrafish. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. These findings have implications for the role of ALKALs in cancer and for the development of neural crest-derived tissues in vivo. Our results also provide a model for studying the role of ALKALs in cancer and in neural crest development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a topic of great interest. The study of ancient plague genomes can provide insights into the origins of this pathogen and its adaptation to its new host. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period. We show that the LNBA Y. pestis lineage was nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct, and that it was replaced by a lineage adapted to the flea in the Bronze Age. We also show that the spread of the flea-adapted form of plague was much wider geographically than previously thought. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its adaptation to humans. (Read more)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors.
