The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate change science and agriculture. We investigated the effects of soil management on SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions in a 29-y-old field experiment in the North Central United States. We found that soil management practices that minimized soil disturbance, diversified crop rotations, and added manure to annual cropping systems increased SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. Our findings have implications for the global carbon cycle and the ability of agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from a virus discovery project, we validated the risk assessment and ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a proxy for the color of the reward, but the mechanisms that underlie this color change are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment, which is likely to be a key component of the plant’s pollination strategy. We also identify the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae as a convergent adaptation to vertebrate pollination. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. It also suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work may have implications for the evolution of vertebrate pollination in other plant lineages. (Read more)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, which has shaped the modern European population structure. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a panel of 41 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Our results also suggest that the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change is more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings have implications for the development of vaccines and therapeutics against bat coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based platform to sequence pathogen RNA from 464 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to rapidly identify the pathogen landscape in other resource-scarce settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication fork progression. This process is catalyzed by the enzyme DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms that govern the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in DNA replication. This information is critical for the development of therapeutic strategies to treat cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA and synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we report the successful evolution of such a ribozyme.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic fortunes of neighborhoods.

COVID-19 is a new disease, and the pathogenesis is still unclear. The immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 have been analyzed. The results show that the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability to control copper levels is therefore important for the survival of fungi. In this study, we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide compounds that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. We also show that these compounds have antimicrobial properties and that copper-dependent antimicrobial properties are conserved in other filamentous fungi. These results suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the control of copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This is the first report of a fungal natural product that binds copper. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This knowledge may be useful in the development of antifungal agents. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant and animal productivity, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is expected to increase in the future. However, the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary adaptations of plants to LSFs are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of temperate and boreal woody species to show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is associated with the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to LSFs are likely to be insufficient to cope with the increasing spring-frost risk in the future. Our findings highlight the need for adaptation in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. They also provide a framework to study the evolutionary adaptation of plants to environmental changes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear whether Th17 cells are required for disease or are merely a component of the disease response. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to disease by inducing the development of Th1-like cells. In addition, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is a complex community that plays important roles in the health of the host. In this study, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) in the tick, Ixodes scapularis. IAFGP is a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. IAFGP perturbs the gut microbiota of the tick, which influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier—critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance colonization. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in avian evolution, as it is the last major modification that led to the evolution of flight. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is therefore crucial for understanding the origin of flight. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times in frogs and toads, and that this ability is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when the pigment in the blood, called hemoglobin, breaks down.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified as either luminal or basal, depending on their expression of a set of genes. Basal-like breast cancer cells are more aggressive and are associated with a poor prognosis. In this study, we show that breast cancer cells exposed to hypoxia express more basal-like genes, and that this is mediated by hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-dependent expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase. ALKBH5 expression is increased in basal-like breast cancer cells, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in breast cancer cells is induced by hypoxia, and this may contribute to the development of basal-like breast cancer. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation in the book trade, and the source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy. We have developed a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did find evidence for the use of more than one species in a single manuscript. This suggests that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been a major innovation in the book trade, allowing the production of a new type of book.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the event. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is based on five ash beds, each of which is interpreted as a deposition of a major volcanic eruption. The age model is consistent with the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately preceding the initiation of extinction. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The new age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Read more)

The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment, and intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The intestinal epithelium is composed of two cell types, the absorptive enterocytes and the immune-protective mucus-secreting goblet cells. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This finding may help to explain the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, a decline of 1.13 y, the lowest in the country since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, which would increase the Black−White life expectancy gap to over 5 y. These projections imply that, in the absence of the pandemic, the Black−White life expectancy gap would have been eliminated by 2020.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are widely used in chemistry. In this paper, we calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, chemical hardness and electronegativity, and show that they decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is expected to be of interest to chemists and physicists.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the implications for the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have the potential to reduce global warming by up to 10 y at today’s levels. However, climate change is expected to reduce fire activity, which could reverse this and enhance land carbon uptake. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon in a changing world.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a classic model for studying the evolution of mutualism. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan to its symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the symbiotic organ. This glycan is delivered only at night, when the squid is not active, and is metabolized by the symbiont to enhance the pH of the organ. This, in turn, increases the availability of oxygen to the symbiont, which is required for its bioluminescence. We propose that this is a general strategy for regulating the activities of symbionts in their host’s epithelium. This mechanism may be used by other hosts to control the activities of their symbionts. (Read more)

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, which is still relevant today, as the disease is currently spreading in Europe.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss would have a significant impact on the ecosystem. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has been described as a mass wasting event. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. We also show that the disease is associated with the loss of the asteroid’s turgor, and that the virus is transmitted by the sea star’s predators. This study provides evidence that the disease is caused by a densovirus, and that it is transmitted by the sea star’s predators.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia. Finally, we found that the genomic diversity is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a heterogeneous way. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar. They also show that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia. This is important because it shows that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a heterogeneous way.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We found that overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that the RNA base pairs with the cadA and galE genes, and that translation of the RNA interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. The translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past. We believe that this RNA is important for carbon utilization in E. coli.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and manage agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often difficult to access and use. We show how to transform the original qualitative data from the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey into a continuous probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC survey is a valuable source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This information can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts and to support decision-making in the agricultural sector.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process. We show that the firing rates of neurons can be reduced through adaptive changes in conductances, which in turn can store information. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of photosynthetic organisms. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not known. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of downscaling to the regional scale to accurately quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to extreme droughts. This study is relevant to water resource managers and policy makers in SSA. It also highlights the need for urgent action to mitigate climate change. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized condensed-matter physics. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the fifth ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key step in this pathway. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in microglia/macrophages, astrocytes, or both. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage. Our findings suggest that ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions are important in the pathophysiology of MS. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities. Our results have important implications for water resources management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a molecular mechanism for autism-risk genes and a potential target for therapeutic intervention. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present in 17 countries across 6 continents. However, individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is also evident, and this work highlights the potential for more positive content to be more widely shared. These findings suggest that the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads” may be overstated. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a major regulator of intracellular Ca2+ and is implicated in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. In this study, we identify two mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in gain-of-function of the CRAC channel and in a range of clinical conditions. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain. We show that these aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and that this process is dependent on endocytosis. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The bat is the only mammal capable of flying, and bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the mechanisms that facilitate the transmission of viruses from bats to other animals and humans are poorly understood. Here, we identified a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein, named MTX, is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit the generation of the potent lipid chemoattractant leukotriene B4 (LTB4). This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of viral spillover from bats to other animals and humans. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to control viral spillover from bats. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth, and that this effect is rooted in a metabolic dependency of colon cancer cells. We also show that a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma makes them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that can be exploited for therapeutic benefit. This work provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a class of cancer therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. In this study, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. We hypothesize that this is due to a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, which results in a metastable state of the inclusions. This metastable state is likely to be the cause of the disease.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the early diversification of the group is poorly resolved. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, raises questions about the origin of the flowering plants. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to the modern genus Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key component of our understanding of the origin of life and the evolution of life on Earth. Here we present the genomes of five ancient human parvoviruses, which are the oldest known human viruses. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The study also shows that the evolution of viruses is not restricted to the last few thousand years.

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and well-known indicators of climate change. In this study, we use satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y. We find that the acceleration is best fit by a quadratic, which implies that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. This finding is consistent with the results of climate models, which project that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. Our results suggest that the rate of sea level rise will continue to accelerate in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study highlights the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology, and the resulting insights into the reaction pathway of this defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes. This work also demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the role of water in enzyme catalysis. This study is a significant step toward the goal of NMR-assisted crystallography as a tool for mechanistic enzymology. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses. The availability of effective antiviral treatments is critical to reduce the impact of this disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a model for the study of host–microbe interactions. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan, chitin, in a cyclic manner, just before dusk, and that this glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont. We also show that the squid provides a second glycan, which is required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which is used by the symbiont to produce bioluminescence. These results suggest that the glycan is a key nutrient that is provided cyclically to the symbiont, whose catabolism modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbiont. This, in turn, may affect the stability of the symbiosis. This is a mechanism that may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts. (Read more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with the most dramatic increases among students of color. This study tests whether teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline—to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. The study also tests whether such a mindset can be sustained over time. The results are promising.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion is error-free, whereas a dominant error-prone route is observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of the spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. In the UK, the food system is responsible for 10–15% of greenhouse gas emissions, and this proportion is likely to increase as the population grows and diets change. In the UK, 20% of greenhouse gas emissions come from the food system, and this proportion is likely to increase as the population grows and diets change. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria increased vegetarian meal sales by 61.8% and decreased meat meal sales by 14.5%. These results have implications for the food system more generally, and for the food service sector in particular.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and found that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We also found massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome, and differential increases in complex hybrid glycans, especially for KRAS and HER2 oncogenes. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a resource for the breast cancer research community. This resource is available at: https://github.com/jwanglab/oncogene_surfaceome.git. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked” for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). The ETV2-induced conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is mediated by the activation of FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, which are important transcription factors for endothelial development. ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This strategy may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTK biology. In this study, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands display a strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also opens up the possibility of using zebrafish as a model to study the role of augmentor ligands in human diseases.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of immune response. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in β-cells, leading to glucose intolerance. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight genomic RNA segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the packaging process of influenza A viruses. It also provides a possible explanation for the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This knowledge might be useful for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, including disturbed flow. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. In addition, treatment with statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited YAP/TAZ activities to diminish the disturbed flow-induced inflammation. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to the loss of forest and rangeland ecosystems. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic fortunes of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of anthropogenic and natural stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a direct consequence of the altered nutrient cycling that occurs during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to preserve this unique and valuable ecosystem.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the maintenance of homeostasis. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and that the microbiome can alter the activity of tumors. We also show that the activity of JNK signaling is a key factor in this feedback loop. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a model for the study of the interplay between tumors and the microbiome in cancer. This model can be used to identify potential therapeutic targets to control the activity of JNK signaling and to restore homeostasis in the intestinal epithelium. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and the majority of patients die. In this study, we show that the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1 is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stemness. We also show that the activation of these pathways is enhanced in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. Finally, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by a comprehensive analysis of the paleoclimate record. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, coincident with the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong El Niño-like climate event, which, in turn, led to a shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. This is the first time that a volcanic eruption has been shown to have caused a climate event, and it provides a plausible mechanism for the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere. This study also shows that the Southern Hemisphere climate system was already in a highly unstable state, which may have contributed to the rapid onset of deglaciation. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and policy discussions, despite their importance to biodiversity, food security, and livelihoods. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis highlights the need to protect the remaining biodiversity of rivers and lakes, as well as the food security of the world’s poor.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost in the adult, and the reasons for this loss are not well understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous chromosomes during meiosis. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing organisms. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are more concentrated in promoters of genes than in other regions of the genome. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the mechanisms that generate hotspots in these organisms may have been conserved in the evolution of flowering plants.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a number of topographies, or networks, that are significantly different from one another. Here, we used metabolic PET to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant (first component) metabolic RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN). In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. The dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, the subordinate RSNs were activated during task performance in healthy subjects and advanced Parkinson’s disease. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. In addition, the 5′ cap structure is the site of modification by the addition of phosphate groups and methyl groups. In bacteria, the 5′ cap structure is modified by the addition of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). In this study, we show that the 5′ cap structure in yeast is modified by NAD+. We also show that the 5′ cap structure is not required for translation of yeast mRNAs. Thus, the 5′ cap structure in yeast is different from that in bacteria. This finding raises the possibility that the 5′ cap structure in yeast is involved in regulation of translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in whole blood (WB) and monocytes (Monos) of people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. We also show that high glucose induces similar persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in cultured monocytes, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results provide a basis for further studies to elucidate the mechanisms of metabolic memory and its potential for therapeutic intervention. This article is protected by copyright. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of a recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that is associated with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. These findings may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for both fundamental and applied reasons. In this study, we describe the biosynthesis of a group of nitrogenous volatile compounds in tomato fruit. We show that the biosynthesis of these compounds is distinct from that of other classes of volatile compounds, and we describe a mechanism for the formation of these compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in tomato fruit, and it will be of interest to other researchers working on the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in other species.

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are more severe when species diversity is low. This is because diversity is required to maintain the thermal tolerance of species, and the loss of diversity reduces the chances of including species with thermal tolerance traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of anthropogenic change on the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key region for navigation, and its activity is thought to be organized into a map of local space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying this region in freely behaving animals. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main cell type involved in the formation of the space map, are anatomically organized in a distinct layer, while other cell types are mixed. These findings suggest that the formation of the space map might be more complex than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can be used by a parasitic plant to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This is an example of how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here we describe a previously unrecognized type of nigral cell–dopamine neuron connection, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets.” These are highly specialized connections within the nigral system that are likely to be affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. We also describe the presence of striosomal fibers within the bouquets, which are likely to be involved in the transmission of information between the striosome and the dopamine neuron.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their function is tightly regulated by a variety of mechanisms. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. We found that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, which we call SAN cells (SANCs). We show that STIM1 is required for the maintenance of SAN function, as evidenced by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. We also show that STIM1 regulates SAN function by modulating the activity of the calcium store-operated channel Orai1 and the activity of the calcium channels. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the SAN and provide a mechanism for how STIM1 may be used as a therapeutic target in the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense responses. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process. We show that the firing rates of neurons can be reduced through adaptive changes in conductances, which in turn can store information. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time.
