The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plant cells is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. Nutrient loading from small tributaries is a major driver of coastal eutrophication, but it has been overlooked in many studies. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, even though they represent only a small proportion of the total watershed area. Our results suggest that small watersheds may be important in fueling algal blooms in nearshore areas, especially given the likelihood that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone. Our findings highlight the need to address nutrient management in small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in thermodynamics, which asks why the environment is not biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We show that the environment can be biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations only by making them available to the system through a network of chemical reactions.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of in silico and in vivo experiments to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, which can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. These findings may help to inform the development of new therapies for this devastating disease. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2, which is thought to be the result of anthropogenic emissions. However, the impact of this increase on the Earth system is not well understood. Here, we present a case study of a rapid global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and that the warming was accompanied by an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean. These results highlight the potential for a rapid global warming event to occur in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced tropical deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to the protection of intact forest. These findings are important for the future of sustainability certification in the palm oil sector and beyond.

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of an individual. In this study, we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles produces a modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. The modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This study also provides a case study of the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a species with a modular system of sexual polymorphism.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe is a key factor in the photodegradation of bisretinoids. Understanding the role of Fe in the photodegradation of bisretinoids may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understand the functioning of the food web. In this study, we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) has been linked to the evolution of prey type. We also show that the evolution of prey specialization is not a dead end, and that prey specialization can evolve into prey generalization. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also contribute to the broader perspective of predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene to recent East African hominin site of Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya, that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the hominin hand. (Read more)

Cancer cells have a number of metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited to treat cancer. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited to treat cancer. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and for the development of a metabolic vulnerability-based strategy to treat cancer. The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This approach allows for causal inferences to be made, which is not possible using traditional descriptive approaches. We believe that this study will be of interest to researchers and policy makers interested in the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
